segments.content: Written by
Michael Tolkin and Henry Bean
Story by
Michael Tolkin

Rain. Christmas lights. A rusted out '56 Lincoln rattles 

               down the bleak boulevard. In it: JOE STEVENS, an angry, black 

               man in his late 20's, beside him his 10-year-old son, JOE

Joe Jr. stares out the window at passing: boarded buildings, 

               whores with raincoats over their heads trying to flag down a 

               john, a black Santa, a knot of drinkers. Breaking the silence:
Your mother okay?
They stop at a light. Joe Stevens tries to furtively snort a little something. He spots Joe Jr. watching.

dialogue.text: They stop at a light. Joe Stevens tries to furtively snort a little something. He spots Joe Jr. watching.

segments.content: (firm, without irony)
Don't you do this shit, boy. Don't
you ever fuckin' touch it, you hear
me?
Joe Jr. stares, silent; Joe Jr.'s about to hit him.
(continuing)
The boy nods. Satisfied, Joe Sr. draws in the stuff. It makes him feel good, strong, worried and determined all at once.

dialogue.text: The boy nods. Satisfied, Joe Sr. draws in the stuff. It makes him feel good, strong, worried and determined all at once.

segments.content: (continuing; charged
up)
What do you want for Christmas?
I don't know.
(light changes; he
accelerates)
You don't know?? You gotta know what
you want, boy, if you ever expect to
get it.
A sudden charm to his bravado. Joe Jr. smiles uncertainly.
Joe Sr. grins back, pulls up in front of a liquor store.
(continuing)

Joe Jr. doesn't notice or doesn't remark that his father, just before entering the store, draws a handgun from beneath his coat. The boy gazes dreamily at the street. The lunatic Black Santa marches by, ranting to himself ("Then the white man say..."). The RAIN HAMMERS on the roof and windshield. Joe Jr. breathes on the glass, fogging the scene. From the store: MUFFLED GUNFIRE. Joe Jr. looks that way. Another GUNSHOT, then: His father comes out the door clutching money in one hand. He strides toward the car with a reckless pride. He doesn't notice: The liquor store door opens behind him. A SHOTGUN BLAST. Joe Stevens' guts splatter onto the car windshield. A look of terrible amazement; he sinks to his knees.

character.name: Wait here. This won't take a minute.

dialogue.text: Joe Jr. doesn't notice or doesn't remark that his father, just before entering the store, draws a handgun from beneath his coat. The boy gazes dreamily at the street. The lunatic Black Santa marches by, ranting to himself ("Then the white man say..."). The RAIN HAMMERS on the roof and windshield. Joe Jr. breathes on the glass, fogging the scene. From the store: MUFFLED GUNFIRE. Joe Jr. looks that way. Another GUNSHOT, then: His father comes out the door clutching money in one hand. He strides toward the car with a reckless pride. He doesn't notice: The liquor store door opens behind him. A SHOTGUN BLAST. Joe Stevens' guts splatter onto the car windshield. A look of terrible amazement; he sinks to his knees.

segments.content: He jumps from the car, kneels by his father. The STORE OWNER (47, Slavic) drags the gun toward them, bleeding profusely.

dialogue.text: He jumps from the car, kneels by his father. The STORE OWNER (47, Slavic) drags the gun toward them, bleeding profusely.

segments.content: (enraged, almost to
tears)
JOE STEVENS looks at the money in his hand: two 20's, two 5's.

dialogue.text: JOE STEVENS looks at the money in his hand: two 20's, two 5's.

segments.content: Fifty bucks... fifty goddam bucks.
(looks up at his son)
He stuffs the blood-soaked bills in the boy's shirt pocket and dies. Joe Jr. looks up at... THE STORE OWNER Bloody, nearly unconscious, he aims the shotgun at the boy who is too frightened to move.

dialogue.text: He stuffs the blood-soaked bills in the boy's shirt pocket and dies. Joe Jr. looks up at... THE STORE OWNER Bloody, nearly unconscious, he aims the shotgun at the boy who is too frightened to move.

segments.content: The man dies on his feet. As he falls backward, he pulls the trigger, the BLAST shattering the car windows. Cop cars SQUEAL up. Uniformed cops leap out, guns drawn, survey the scene. Then one notices Joe Jr., staring motionless at his father and the store owner, dead together. ON HIS EYES:

dialogue.text: The man dies on his feet. As he falls backward, he pulls the trigger, the BLAST shattering the car windows. Cop cars SQUEAL up. Uniformed cops leap out, guns drawn, survey the scene. Then one notices Joe Jr., staring motionless at his father and the store owner, dead together. ON HIS EYES:

segments.content:
-- but older, harder, colder. They're concentrating on a 

               paper before him.

heading.subject: UP
heading.raw_text: CLOSEUP - THE MINNESOTA MULTIPHASIC PERSONALITY INVENTORY

segments.content:
Hundreds of TRUE/FALSE questions...

               1.) I have never indulged in any unusual sexual practices.

2.) I have often felt that strangers were looking at me 

               critically. (T/F)

               3.) When I was young I occasionally stole things. (T/F)

               Joe Stevens marks these TRUE, FALSE, FALSE then comes to:

               4.) A person's station in life is at least partially 

               determined by his race. (T/F) We are:

Thirty-seven Black Cleveland police officers (many in uniform, 

               including Joe) are taking the MMPI. Some roll their eyes at 

               the questions. Some try to copy answers. Others, like Joe, 

               work with rapid concentration.

               But he gets stuck on #4. Marks it false. Erases it. Marks it 

               true. Erases that. Ponders. Goes on to: #5. At times I hear 

               so well it bothers me. (T/F) He marks that true.

GERALD CARVER, 36, an ambitious government lawyer with a 

               relaxed, vaguely hip manner, looks over the file of the 

               ingratiating BLACK OFFICER sitting across the desk from him.
Officer Leland? You know the
difference between a black man and
nigger?
Leland is startled, insulted, but doesn't want to blow the
interview. He smiles weakly, shakes his head no.
(continuing; pleasant
smile)
Stung, Leland tries to laugh. Carver puts his file aside, picks up another.

dialogue.text: Stung, Leland tries to laugh. Carver puts his file aside, picks up another.

segments.content: (continuing)
INT. SAME - ANOTHER INTERVIEW A SECOND BLACK OFFICER is powerfully built, politically conscious, takes no shit. Carver's leafing through his file.

dialogue.text: INT. SAME - ANOTHER INTERVIEW A SECOND BLACK OFFICER is powerfully built, politically conscious, takes no shit. Carver's leafing through his file.

segments.content: So, Winston, what's the difference
between a black man and a nigger?
Winston is out of his chair before the question is finished,
drags Carver by the shirt front halfway across the desk and
hisses into his face:
Who the fuck do you think you're
talking to?
Carver smiles cheerfully past Winston's cocked fist.

Nonplussed by this cool dismissal, Winston stalks out. Carver picks up the next file, unfazed. INT. SAME - ANOTHER INTERVIEW Joe Stevens watches Carver reading his file and waiting for an answer. When none is forthcoming, Carver glances up, finds Stevens looking right back at him.

dialogue.text: Nonplussed by this cool dismissal, Winston stalks out. Carver picks up the next file, unfazed. INT. SAME - ANOTHER INTERVIEW Joe Stevens watches Carver reading his file and waiting for an answer. When none is forthcoming, Carver glances up, finds Stevens looking right back at him.

segments.content: The nigger's the one who falls for
your bullshit.
He says it pleasantly, without belligerence. Carver smiles:
he's found his man. He offers his hand.
Gerald Carver, United States District

INT. A DARKENED ROOM - DAY/NIGHT ON A TV SCREEN: a grainy black-and-white tape, date and time stamped at the bottom. A grungy street, palm trees. The light from the monitor dimly illuminates Carver and Stevens. On SCREEN the CAMERA finds: A MAN in jeans, sneakers and sweatshirt on a street corner.

dialogue.text: INT. A DARKENED ROOM - DAY/NIGHT ON A TV SCREEN: a grainy black-and-white tape, date and time stamped at the bottom. A grungy street, palm trees. The light from the monitor dimly illuminates Carver and Stevens. On SCREEN the CAMERA finds: A MAN in jeans, sneakers and sweatshirt on a street corner.

segments.content: He ought to be wearing a sign.

Stevens laughs: it's obvious. A real DRUG DEALER joins the cop. UNDERCOVER COP: "You got it?" DEALER: "In the motel, right over here..." The Cop's uneasy, keeps glancing back toward the CAMERA as they go.

character.name: You can tell he's a cop?

dialogue.text: Stevens laughs: it's obvious. A real DRUG DEALER joins the cop. UNDERCOVER COP: "You got it?" DEALER: "In the motel, right over here..." The Cop's uneasy, keeps glancing back toward the CAMERA as they go.

segments.content: He keeps looking for his back-up.
Now, the other guy knows it, too.
Then why's he taking him to the room?
(why else?)

Carver studies Stevens in the darkness, impressed. ON SCREEN: The figures disappear into the motel. We hear their voices. DEALER: "Here, try some of it." UNDERCOVER COP: "Uhh... No, I don't..." DEALER: "Why not, you sonofabitch?" Two bursts of SOUND DISTORTION. A plainclothes cop, TAFT, (black, stocky, powerful) bolts from behind the CAMERA, sprints toward the motel. The CAMERA wobbles after him.

dialogue.text: Carver studies Stevens in the darkness, impressed. ON SCREEN: The figures disappear into the motel. We hear their voices. DEALER: "Here, try some of it." UNDERCOVER COP: "Uhh... No, I don't..." DEALER: "Why not, you sonofabitch?" Two bursts of SOUND DISTORTION. A plainclothes cop, TAFT, (black, stocky, powerful) bolts from behind the CAMERA, sprints toward the motel. The CAMERA wobbles after him.

segments.content: (continuing)
ON SCREEN: The CAMERA (jerky, hand-held) nears the open motel door. Taft is bent over the Undercover Cop's body.

dialogue.text: ON SCREEN: The CAMERA (jerky, hand-held) nears the open motel door. Taft is bent over the Undercover Cop's body.

segments.content: Oh, Bobby... Jesus, Jesus...
(to the CAMERA)
Get an ambulance -- and back up.
He slams the wall, starts past the CAMERA. Carver pushes the pause button; the tape freezes on a jerky image of Taft's face.

dialogue.text: He slams the wall, starts past the CAMERA. Carver pushes the pause button; the tape freezes on a jerky image of Taft's face.

segments.content: (focussed on Taft)
Who is he?
Charles Taft. LAPD Narcotics.
He's a good cop.
He's a great cop. Two [names citation]
and a [another citation]. As tough
as they come and twice as honest.
Carver watches Stevens watch Taft, smiles at something.
But the cops aren't getting it done
here, are they? Gotta try something
new...
He opens a manila envelope, dumps the contents on the desk:
driver's license, social security card, high school
transcript, prison records... all in the name of William G.
Hull. No photos.
(continuing)
Who's John Hull?
You are. If you want to be.
(off Stevens)
Most undercover guys don't know what
they're doing because it's a day
gig.
(indicates dead cop
on TV)
I need somebody who goes under and
stays there; six months, a year,
five years...
What does he have to do?
Buy drugs. Sell drugs. Feed me
information.
He's a snitch.
He's a drug dealer. A criminal. A
scumbag. But for the right side.
(beat)
I want you to come to Los Angeles on
loan to the Justice Department as a
federal agent. Your experience there
will be credited toward your seniority
here. And you'll come back to
Cleveland a P3 or higher.
(uncomfortable)
I can't do that. I've got a wife and
kids.
You're separated from your wife,
she's filled for divorce. You see
your kids every other weekend.
Stevens takes a breath: this is awkward to explain.
(almost a confession)
All my life I've stayed away from
that stuff. I've never touched drugs.
(tolerant)
Come on, a little grass...?
Not grass. Not nothing. I never even
had a drink.
(his motto)
Never have, never will. You don't
understand. I made a choice in my
life.
What's to understand? You saw your
father killed when you were ten, and
you decided you wouldn't be like
that.
(off Stevens' surprise,
Carver grins)
I'm God, I know everything. You wanted
to be a good boy, so you became a
cop. Hiding out in uniform... That's
why you got the hard-on for Taft.
It's not that simple.
(opening Joe's file;
as if reluctantly)
I'll tell the truth, Joe. You're
never going to be a Taft.
But he does.

dialogue.text: But he does.

segments.content: (looks at MMPI results)
You ever take a look at your
psychological profile? You score
almost like a criminal.
(reading)
"Resents authority..."
I do not.
"...Exaggerated moral standards, but
with no underlying value system."
Look at the anger, the repressed
violence, it's almost off the scale...
Carver hands him the scores which are, of course, just clusters of numbers. Stevens is upset, though oddly unsurprised, as if this only confirmed his secret fears.

dialogue.text: Carver hands him the scores which are, of course, just clusters of numbers. Stevens is upset, though oddly unsurprised, as if this only confirmed his secret fears.

segments.content: Why'd you join the force?
(awkward, but felt)
I wanted to be of use.
Well, now you can be. You won't be
Taft, but maybe you'll be something
more... interesting.
(sits back)
There's a man named Ramon Gallegos
who supplies 60% of the cocaine to
the West Coast. He's smart, smooth,
and sufficiently elusive that we
don't even have an adult photograph
of him. However, his uncle is Hector
Guzman, an important Latin American
political figure. Gallegos uses
Uncle's connections to get product
into the country, and everyone we've
sent after him has ended up like
that...
Indicates dead body on TV.
Why would I be different?

heading.subject: You already are, that's the point...
heading.raw_text: You already are, that's the point...

segments.content: (indicates file, test
scores)
You've got the ability and the
personality to go underground and
blend in completely. That's what the
others couldn't. Some part of them
showed. That's why they're dead.
See, there's only one rule in this
game.
Stevens raises his eyebrows: what?
(continuing)

EXT. WORKING CLASS CLEVELAND NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY Stevens parks outside a small, well-maintained house. As he gets out, he spots a GROUP OF KIDS (black and Hispanic) playing down the street. He's not pleased about that.

dialogue.text: EXT. WORKING CLASS CLEVELAND NEIGHBORHOOD - DAY Stevens parks outside a small, well-maintained house. As he gets out, he spots a GROUP OF KIDS (black and Hispanic) playing down the street. He's not pleased about that.

segments.content: (calls to them)
A BOY, 7, and a GIRL, 5, (both light-skinned) run to him shouting, "Daddy," jump into his arms, competing for attention, as if they haven't seen him in ages.

dialogue.text: A BOY, 7, and a GIRL, 5, (both light-skinned) run to him shouting, "Daddy," jump into his arms, competing for attention, as if they haven't seen him in ages.

segments.content: What were you doing with those kids?
Playing...
(displeased)
Your mom lets you play with them?

His strictness has already sobered their enthusiasm. Sensing this, he attempts to embrace them which he can do only awkwardly. Meanwhile, his wife, TERRY (Southern white) has come out the screen door. She and Stevens bristle at each other.

dialogue.text: His strictness has already sobered their enthusiasm. Sensing this, he attempts to embrace them which he can do only awkwardly. Meanwhile, his wife, TERRY (Southern white) has come out the screen door. She and Stevens bristle at each other.

segments.content: I thought we talked about this. The
older brother up there's got a sheet
with --
Both are ready to fight, but restrain themselves. A big Polynesian, TITO comes out the door.

character.name: Lay off it. They're just kids...

dialogue.text: Both are ready to fight, but restrain themselves. A big Polynesian, TITO comes out the door.

segments.content: Hey, Joe.

A moment of surprise, then he gets it. He looks to Terry. She gives a little shrug, refusing to be embarrassed. INT. KITCHEN - FIVE MINUTES LATER Stevens is trying to seem interested in Carmen's little drawings.

dialogue.text: A moment of surprise, then he gets it. He looks to Terry. She gives a little shrug, refusing to be embarrassed. INT. KITCHEN - FIVE MINUTES LATER Stevens is trying to seem interested in Carmen's little drawings.

segments.content: They're real nice, honey. Is that a
horse?
(exasperated)
She puts her arms around him.

dialogue.text: She puts her arms around him.

segments.content: (continuing)
I don't want you to go away, Daddy.
Over her shoulder he sees Terry sitting with a subdued Joe- J. Her face seems to say, "See, I told you..." Avoiding this accusation, Stevens notices a bruise on Carmen's arm.

character.name: It's my work. I've got to.

dialogue.text: Over her shoulder he sees Terry sitting with a subdued Joe- J. Her face seems to say, "See, I told you..." Avoiding this accusation, Stevens notices a bruise on Carmen's arm.

segments.content: (continuing)
What happened to you there, baby?
Tito did it.
(instantly outraged)
He hit you?!
(up in a fury)
God damn it, what's he doing touching
her? I'm gonna...
Terry intercepts him on his way out of the room.
She was running behind his chair
when he got up. It was an accident.
(he's uncertain)
Stevens looks at Carmen who giggles. He's humiliated by his own temper, attempts to calm himself. Terry puts a sympathetic hand on his shoulder.

dialogue.text: Stevens looks at Carmen who giggles. He's humiliated by his own temper, attempts to calm himself. Terry puts a sympathetic hand on his shoulder.

heading.subject: SHOT
heading.raw_text: EXT. LOS ANGELES - AERIAL SHOT - DAY

segments.content:
The immense sprawl, the arterial flow of the freeways, the 

               blinding light. We DESCEND...

heading.raw_text: INT. TRAIN STATION - UNDERGROUND - DAY OR NIGHT

segments.content:
People getting off, among them the former Joe Stevens, now 

               known as JOHN HULL. He's carrying a suitcase.
Hull goes up the stairs onto a downtown street.

South L.A. neighborhood. A 13-year-old BLACK YOUTH selling 

               drugs through a car window. Hull walks by. He's at ease, 

               looking around, his manner subtly announcing that he belongs 

               here, just as in the train station he seemed to belong among 

               the commuters.

A fat BLONDE WOMAN (61, large white glasses, tiny shoes) 

               leads Hull down a corridor.
Television mostly. I was on "Sky
King" twice, "Ramar of the Jungle."
That was a silly show. The jungle
was mostly flats...
They pass an open door where a 6-year-old boy, JAMES, a
latchkey, sits on the stoop playing Gameboy; inside, his
mother, BELINDA, a broken down whore, is doing her nails and
drinking Pepsi. She looks up, bats her lashes at Hull.
(continuing)
You want my advice, I'd stay away
from that bitch.
She opens the door to the room across the hall. A dump. Hull
walks in, drops his duffle: he'll take it. The Blonde lounges
in the doorway. He closes the door.

Hull empties his pockets on the dresser. Looks at his money, 

               room key, identification. Looks at himself in the mirror. He 

               touches his clothes, his face, tries on different expressions.

               (NOTE: Throughout the film, Hull continually checks himself 

               out in mirrors, both to adjust his appearance to the 

               circumstances and as if in an attempt to recall who he 

               "really" is.)

On the seam between South-Central and USC. Lots of people 

               out: children, students, dealers, whores. Hull with a new 

               haircut.

Dealers (most in mid-teens) meeting cars, making transactions. 

               All this casually observed. EDDIE comes up the street, 

               reciting his version of an old street toast.
On the day of the King's castration,
all the counts and no accounts were
down on the deck with Georgia Tech
taking turns in the back seat...
Those dealers not at car windows, gather around. He never
speaks to them, goes on declaiming as he exchanges drugs for
money.
Hull watches, talking to another street person. His appearance
continues to change: clothes, posture, walk, gestures subtly
conform to the environment, a bit like Zelig. Throughout the
film his appearance shifts, depending on who he's with. We
always recognize him, but each time he's different.
He walks up to a dealer, makes a quick buy and keeps going.
But he sees them and is seen.

Hull drops eleven foil balls on a green blotter. Carver counts 

               out money for him.

He sits at the window, eating a burrito, watching little 

               James play in the courtyard.

Hull approaches another Dealer, the 13-year-old seen earlier 

               (angelic face). Like Hull, he's trying to act tough.
Whatta you got?
(voice just changing)
Nickel rock, dime rock. Excellent
shit.
Hull exchanges a folded twenty for two foil balls. He walks
off. He has gone twenty feet when...

SQUEALS to a stop opposite the Dealer.

               A huge young black man, IVY (23, all in red with a red 

               headband), leans out the passenger window, shouting at the 

               13-year-old.
What the fuck I tell you about being
here?
Everyone turns to look, but Hull's view is blocked.
No, wait...
POPPING noises. Ivy is waving an automatic weapon. Everyone on the street but Hull has hit the ground.

dialogue.text: POPPING noises. Ivy is waving an automatic weapon. Everyone on the street but Hull has hit the ground.

segments.content: (enjoying it, shouting)

Ivy laughs and fondles a girlfriend as the car ROARS off. He sees Hull, pretends to fire, laughs as Hull, too, ducks. When Ivy's gone, he runs to where a CROWD has gathered around... THE 13-YEAR-OLD lying in the street, a bullet hole in his head, eyes open. He twitches and kicks, blood pulsing from the neat wound. Then he's dead. The faces around him (young, old, many races) watch with a variety of emotions.

dialogue.text: Ivy laughs and fondles a girlfriend as the car ROARS off. He sees Hull, pretends to fire, laughs as Hull, too, ducks. When Ivy's gone, he runs to where a CROWD has gathered around... THE 13-YEAR-OLD lying in the street, a bullet hole in his head, eyes open. He twitches and kicks, blood pulsing from the neat wound. Then he's dead. The faces around him (young, old, many races) watch with a variety of emotions.

segments.content: Who is he?... Why'd they shoot him?...
Ivy did him, man... He's in the wrong
fuckin' place... That poor boy...

Cops push through to the body. As the crowd disperses, Hull can't take his eyes off the boy. When he finally does, he sees Eddie, drink in hand. Their eyes meet, and Eddie, a rapper, raises his eyebrows in brief acknowledgment of sorrow.

dialogue.text: Cops push through to the body. As the crowd disperses, Hull can't take his eyes off the boy. When he finally does, he sees Eddie, drink in hand. Their eyes meet, and Eddie, a rapper, raises his eyebrows in brief acknowledgment of sorrow.

segments.content: (sadly)

EXT. LEWAZZ - NIGHT TITLE: TWO WEEKS LATER A bar with a neon bird for a sign. Hull enters. INT. LEWAZZ - NIGHT A racial mix. Hull takes a seat at the bar. Stuffed birds line the lintel above the bottles. A female BARTENDER (long red nails) greets him familiarly.

dialogue.text: EXT. LEWAZZ - NIGHT TITLE: TWO WEEKS LATER A bar with a neon bird for a sign. Hull enters. INT. LEWAZZ - NIGHT A racial mix. Hull takes a seat at the bar. Stuffed birds line the lintel above the bottles. A female BARTENDER (long red nails) greets him familiarly.

segments.content: How's it going, John?

Without being asked, she sets him up a Dry Sack with a long red straw. (NOTE: He never touches the drink.) Hull's appearance has continued to change. His clothes have become flashier, he has an earring, the start of a goatee. Eddie approaches the bar compulsively reciting one of his toasts.

dialogue.text: Without being asked, she sets him up a Dry Sack with a long red straw. (NOTE: He never touches the drink.) Hull's appearance has continued to change. His clothes have become flashier, he has an earring, the start of a goatee. Eddie approaches the bar compulsively reciting one of his toasts.

segments.content: (to himself)
"Where's the Queen," said the King.
"She's in bed with laryngitis." "Is
that bastard still in town?... Fuck
the Queen," said the King, and ten
thousand knights straaaained at their
utmost...
(to the bartender)
Pina colada times two and a white
wine.
He goes on muttering under his breath, tapping his foot like
any crankhead. He notices Hull, greets him as someone he
can't place but knows he's seen around.
(continuing)
Tries to remember name.

dialogue.text: Tries to remember name.

segments.content: John.

Clasp hands. Eddie takes his drinks, carries them to... A TABLE where he rejoins a white man, DAVID ELIAS (30s, slick, powerful) and a well-dressed BLACK WOMAN (mid-20s, good- looking). She gets the wine. Elias rises to let her out. As the woman passes Hull on her way to the restrooms, their eyes meet: an instant of perfect chemistry. He's struck. Her features open, grow sensual for a moment, but then, as if seeing something she doesn't like, her eyes flick away, and she walks by as if he weren't there. INT. CARVER'S OFFICE - NIGHT (NOTE: Hull invariably meets Carver in this anonymous room, distinguished only by the green blotter and a view of the city. This simple regularity suggest visits to a psychiatrist, Carver probing, testing, teasing, trying to draw Hull out. And they feel like therapy, at once a respite and a torment.) More foil balls on the blotter beside boxes of 3x5 photographs. Photos of Eddie and David Elias are up on a corkboard, the beginning of a pyramid.

dialogue.text: Clasp hands. Eddie takes his drinks, carries them to... A TABLE where he rejoins a white man, DAVID ELIAS (30s, slick, powerful) and a well-dressed BLACK WOMAN (mid-20s, good- looking). She gets the wine. Elias rises to let her out. As the woman passes Hull on her way to the restrooms, their eyes meet: an instant of perfect chemistry. He's struck. Her features open, grow sensual for a moment, but then, as if seeing something she doesn't like, her eyes flick away, and she walks by as if he weren't there. INT. CARVER'S OFFICE - NIGHT (NOTE: Hull invariably meets Carver in this anonymous room, distinguished only by the green blotter and a view of the city. This simple regularity suggest visits to a psychiatrist, Carver probing, testing, teasing, trying to draw Hull out. And they feel like therapy, at once a respite and a torment.) More foil balls on the blotter beside boxes of 3x5 photographs. Photos of Eddie and David Elias are up on a corkboard, the beginning of a pyramid.

segments.content: Eddie something... a motormouth...
he supplies the street dealers...
buys from him...
(reads name on back
of photo)
David Elias... who apparently buys
from a guy named Barbolla or
something. But I haven't seen him.
Carver produces a photo of a handsome Latin in his 50s, pins
it on the board above Elias.
Barbosa, Felix.
There was also a woman, but she's
not here.
(as Carver reaches in
a drawer)
I saw a kid killed. Twelve, thirteen
at the most. Turf war.
Carver shrugs: these things happen. He hands Hull a lot of
cash, much more than expected. Hull does understand.
Get to Elias. Then to Barbosa.
You can't rush this stuff.
Rush it, please. I want art, John,
not reality. Budget hearings start
in April, and I need Gallegos by
then. They won't give us funding for
three ounce buys.
We're not just doing this for the
funding, are we?
Without funding, we aren't doing it
at all.

Virtual darkness save splinters of light between the curtains. 

               Pipes burn here and there in the gloom. Ten or fifteen 

               crackheads huddle around a battery-operated TV on which Tom 

               Brokaw is narrating an NBC documentary on drugs. A 12-year-

               old sits against a wall too stoned even for television.

               Hull approaches Eddie, regally installed on an automobile 

               bench seat-cum-sofa, a lit pipe in one hand. We barely notice 

               the redhead kneeling between his legs, face buried in his 

               crotch. He greets Hull from wrecked bliss. They know each 

               other now.
Hull greets Eddie, some of the others, drops familiarly onto an adjacent auto seat. The patrons are making fun of Brokaw, laughing, exchanging fives.

character.name: My man, Dudley, he's so fud-ley...

dialogue.text: Hull greets Eddie, some of the others, drops familiarly onto an adjacent auto seat. The patrons are making fun of Brokaw, laughing, exchanging fives.

segments.content: Eddie holds up a hand telling Hull to wait. His mind is elsewhere. His features contract in brief concentration.

dialogue.text: Eddie holds up a hand telling Hull to wait. His mind is elsewhere. His features contract in brief concentration.

segments.content: Whatever happened to that Drug Czar
motherfucker?... He gave up 'cause
he finally realized he didn't know
nothing about any of that shit...
More laughter, etc. Eddie's concentration peaks, breaks off
into a sigh and a smile.
Eddie sings a satisfied little song...
The redhead rises from Eddie's crotch, and we see it's a
boy, seventeen going on death; he might have been pretty a
year ago.
Eddie passes him the crack pipe, lets him suck greedily for
a few seconds before ripping it out of his scabrous mouth
and offering it to Hull, who, with a grimace that gets laughs,
declines. The others continue to watch and comment on the
speech.
So what is it you need so bad, blood?
Need, need, need??
A whole K, quick as you can get it.
(impressed, a trace
of envy)
Comin' in the world, Dudley.
(winning grin)
Eddie likes that, holds out a hand. Hull hits it.

dialogue.text: Eddie likes that, holds out a hand. Hull hits it.

segments.content: Hull nods, rises.

dialogue.text: Hull nods, rises.

segments.content: (continuing)
Stick around, let the bitch Hoover
you, too.
Indicating redhead.
In all these scenes, Hull acts indifferent to the horror,
but here the effort costs him. He masters his disgust with a
joke.
Everyone laughs, even the boy. EXT. STREET - NIGHT Eddie comes out the back door of a building, is immediately collared by Taft (the cop on the videotape). He's in his mid- 40s, stocky, balding.

character.name: Only if you Clorox him first.

dialogue.text: Everyone laughs, even the boy. EXT. STREET - NIGHT Eddie comes out the back door of a building, is immediately collared by Taft (the cop on the videotape). He's in his mid- 40s, stocky, balding.

segments.content: (cheerful, gregarious)
Eddie breaks free, runs three feet before HERNANDEZ (a muscular Mexican) knees him in the groin. Eddie crumples.

character.name: Eddie Shitface! Where you been, boy?

dialogue.text: Eddie breaks free, runs three feet before HERNANDEZ (a muscular Mexican) knees him in the groin. Eddie crumples.

segments.content: (continuing)
Eddie, I don't think I introduced
you to my new partner, Michael
Hernandez...
EXT. STREET - NIGHT Eddie folded over his wounded nuts. Hernandez and Taft sit on crates to either side. The drugs they've taken from him are neatly arranged on a garbage can lid.

character.name: Pleased to meet you, Mr. Shitface...

dialogue.text: EXT. STREET - NIGHT Eddie folded over his wounded nuts. Hernandez and Taft sit on crates to either side. The drugs they've taken from him are neatly arranged on a garbage can lid.

segments.content: You have the right to remain silent...
You have the right to an attorney...
You have the right to go back to
Ontario for eight-to-ten on a second
offense...
(in several kinds of
pain)
Oh, man, I can't go back in there, I
just can't.
(soothing)
'Course you can't, child, 'course
you can't. That's why you're gonna
start giving us some help.
A pleasant, Santa Monica neighborhood. Spanish style house.

Pleasant, tasteful. Elias's wife, NANCY, (dressed like the 

               attorney she is) sits in an alcove-study reading a real estate 

               contract through half-glasses. Elias himself is helping his 

               daughter, MIRANDA, 7, with her homework. He is 38, with the 

               body and bearing of a powerful man.
Again. Three times four.
Elias is not a sweet Daddy. It should make us uncomfortable to watch him push his daughter.

dialogue.text: Elias is not a sweet Daddy. It should make us uncomfortable to watch him push his daughter.

segments.content: No. You're adding again, you have to
multiply. Three and four is seven.
Three times four is...
Twelve.
The DOORBELL.

dialogue.text: The DOORBELL.

segments.content: Can you get that?
Eight.
(getting up; more
about the answer
than the door)
Damn it.

INT./EXT. FRONT DOOR - NIGHT Three men: FELIX BARBOSA (whose photo we saw in Carver's office). Barbosa is a veteran of the coke business, but he's doing too much of the drug now; he's sweating, paranoid, unstable. With him is GOPHER, early 60s, a wizened high-voiced old con who Barbosa keeps the way Spanish kings kept dwarfs, for amusement and luck; like the court jester, Gopher can say anything he wants without fear. Behind them is an Hispanic kid, CHINO, 17, a thug. Elias knows them all, but is not happy to see them at his door.

character.name: Why can't I just use a calculator?

dialogue.text: INT./EXT. FRONT DOOR - NIGHT Three men: FELIX BARBOSA (whose photo we saw in Carver's office). Barbosa is a veteran of the coke business, but he's doing too much of the drug now; he's sweating, paranoid, unstable. With him is GOPHER, early 60s, a wizened high-voiced old con who Barbosa keeps the way Spanish kings kept dwarfs, for amusement and luck; like the court jester, Gopher can say anything he wants without fear. Behind them is an Hispanic kid, CHINO, 17, a thug. Elias knows them all, but is not happy to see them at his door.

segments.content: What are you doing here?
We've got a problem, David.
Call me on the phone.
Your friend Eddie just started bending
over for the cops.
This is very bad news. Elias murmurs a shaken, "Shit..." and
steps outside, half-closing the door behind him.
(continuing)
They busted him, and he's dealing to
save his ass.
Which is how he'll lose the skinny
little thing.
Did he give us up?
Not yet, but he will if he has to,
and eventually he'll have to.
Daddy! I thought we were doing my
homework.
I don't think he'd talk about us.
He'd try not to.
If we whack him, he definitely won't.
Daddy!!
(to Miranda)
Just a second.
(to Barbosa)
Not yet. Let me check on this, first.
(taunting)
Nobody said you had to do the dirty
work, David. I'll take care of --
Felix, if he's a problem, we'll kill
him. I'll kill him myself.
He doesn't realize until it's too late that Nancy has just
then opened the front door to see where he went. They look
at each other, a terrible moment: she knows what he does,
hates it, can't bring herself to leave him, hates herself
for that.
(continuing)
Nancy, get out of here.
She hands him a cordless phone, goes inside closing the door.

dialogue.text: She hands him a cordless phone, goes inside closing the door.

segments.content: You got a tasty wife, David. No wonder
you don't want us coming here.
(warning him)
Barbosa laughs.

character.name: Don't talk about her that way.

dialogue.text: Barbosa laughs.

segments.content: He can't help it, David, it's his
nature.
(into phone, chipper)
INT. A BOXING GYM - NIGHT Elias joins Eddie and Hull to one side. In the b.g. two guys sparring.

character.name: Eddie... Sure, man, what do you need?

dialogue.text: INT. A BOXING GYM - NIGHT Elias joins Eddie and Hull to one side. In the b.g. two guys sparring.

segments.content: David, this is John, John, David.
Eddie, this is Eddie. Everybody ready?
(to Elias)
So what's this, you want to meet me?
(charming, touch of
mockery)
I like to know the important
customers.
Hull makes a show of weary patience, gestures: here I am.
(continuing)
You're taking a lot of weight for a
guy we hardly know. Where're you
moving this stuff, John? We haven't
seen you around. We like to have a
sense who your customers are.
Ah, come on, man, do Macy's tell the
Gimbel motherfuckers?
(beat; watches him)
He gets up, walks away. ON HULL He's blown it. He's been made. The crushing failure. He rallies himself to indignation.

character.name: Eddie, forget this guy, he's a cop.

dialogue.text: He gets up, walks away. ON HULL He's blown it. He's been made. The crushing failure. He rallies himself to indignation.

segments.content: What is this shit, Eddie? I thought
you were the man.
Eddie's sickened, wants to get paid, owes Taft a bust.
Nobody's the fuckin' man. Go to your
place. I'll call you.

heading.raw_text: EXT. GYM/INT. A VAN - CONTINUOUS TIME

segments.content:
Taft and Hernandez, watching the gym. Hull comes out, looks 

               up and down the street carefully. Taft sits up, pays 

               attention.
Hernandez grunts.

dialogue.text: Hernandez grunts.

segments.content: (continuing)
Who is he?

But Taft clearly thinks there's something different about Hull. He's not sure what, but it troubles him. (NOTE: Hull makes a little move that Taft will later realize was a cop's move. For now he can't quite place it.) EXT. PARKING LOT - CONTINUOUS TIME Eddie pleading his case to Elias.

dialogue.text: But Taft clearly thinks there's something different about Hull. He's not sure what, but it troubles him. (NOTE: Hull makes a little move that Taft will later realize was a cop's move. For now he can't quite place it.) EXT. PARKING LOT - CONTINUOUS TIME Eddie pleading his case to Elias.

segments.content: He's no cop, David. He's an animal.
You see his eyes? You never see a
cop with those eyes. I know this
shit, man, you don't.
(giving him an opening)
What's going on, Eddie?
Twenty-six thousand cash is what. We
need it, David. We're behind.
Elias studies Eddie: is he a rat? Elias hopes not, but he's
going to find out. He hands a fat Federal Express envelope
through the window.
(a warning)
Eddie bows in gratitude, hurries off. EXT./INT. HULL'S MOTEL - NIGHT Hull's unlocking his door when Belinda, the hooker across the hall, comes out to talk. Her 6-year-old, James, watches, silent.

character.name: I want him to get it all, Eddie.

dialogue.text: Eddie bows in gratitude, hurries off. EXT./INT. HULL'S MOTEL - NIGHT Hull's unlocking his door when Belinda, the hooker across the hall, comes out to talk. Her 6-year-old, James, watches, silent.

segments.content: (a crackhead)
Mr. Hull... Mr. Hull...
(wearily)
What's happening, Belinda?
Now you know, Mr. Hull, I was to the
welfare this afternoon, but the bus,
you know what I'm saying?... the one
bus, and then the other, and when I
got there they'd gone and changed
the time on me, without notification.
They's supposed to give notification,
ain't they? They said I got a thing
in the mail, but I don't remember, I
don't think they sent it, so now I'm
off the welfare, plus I forgot to

heading.subject: take James for his shot... for the
heading.raw_text: take James for his shot... for the

segments.content: school? Which otherwise they let him
go. And he's gotta learn, he's gotta
learn, don't he, Mr. Hull, you tell
him, so's he can better hisself.
Hull slouches in the doorway, fingers to his eyes.
(to James)
You had any food today, James?
(disclaiming any need)
I had Ding-Dongs.
(sighs, gives him
money)
You go to the Mexican place over
there, and get the chicken tostada
or the beef and bean burrito or both.
And a milk.
I don't like milk. I want a --
(an order)
You get the milk! And get something
for your mother, too.
(to Belinda)
What do you want?
Now, Mr. Hull, if you just --
(to James)
Gives him another bill. The boy runs off.

character.name: Two tostadas, two burritos, two milks.

dialogue.text: Gives him another bill. The boy runs off.

segments.content: You now, I look out for my James
best I can, Mr. Hull, but it's hard.
Hull grunts.

character.name: Now you like the boy, don't you?

dialogue.text: Hull grunts.

segments.content: (continuing)
I know you do. And I was thinkin' if
you wanted to take care of him, that
might be good for him. Give him a
male figure to look up to.
Look, Belinda, I can't...
If you could just give me something
for him. Say five thousand dollars...
(off Hull's shock)
Or maybe four thousand. I couldn't
give up my boy for less than four
thousand...
Hull is rescued from this horror by the ringing PAY PHONE.
He runs down the hall, grabs it.
It's me. I'm here... Where?... five
minutes.
He dashes past Belinda into his room.
Or you could just give me a part
now...
He closes the door, takes the money Carver gave him out from
behind the mirror, dashes back outside. As he rushes by:
(continuing)
Let me do somethin' for you, Mr.
Hull. Let me do a little somethin'
for you.
He keeps going. The Blonde Woman addresses Belinda.
No solicitin' in the halls. I told
you that before.
(spunkier than we've
seen)

EXT. TACO STAND - VENICE AND LA BREA - NIGHT A handful of customers under a mud sky. The THROB of a distant helicopter. Hull pulls into the lot beside Eddie's BMW. He climbs into the BMW, tosses Eddie a brown envelope; money spills onto his lap. Eddie does a quick count, produces the Fed Ex envelope. The usual white stuff. Hull's about to taste when the chopper swoops in with a sudden blinding overhead light. A BULLHORN booms down like the voice of God.

dialogue.text: EXT. TACO STAND - VENICE AND LA BREA - NIGHT A handful of customers under a mud sky. The THROB of a distant helicopter. Hull pulls into the lot beside Eddie's BMW. He climbs into the BMW, tosses Eddie a brown envelope; money spills onto his lap. Eddie does a quick count, produces the Fed Ex envelope. The usual white stuff. Hull's about to taste when the chopper swoops in with a sudden blinding overhead light. A BULLHORN booms down like the voice of God.

segments.content: This is the police. Remain inside
the vehicle. Place your open hands
against the windshield so that they
are clearly visible...
Christ...
(a strategy)
Spread the floor, Dudley.
(rap sound effects
with rhythmic head
spasms)

Eddie starts the car, and Hull rolls out the passenger door as the BMW races across the lot. Two black-and-whites and an unmarked converge on the stand. Hull can't reach his car. He vaults a metal rail and runs off between two buildings. Hernandez jumps out of an unmarked and races after him. Taft speeds the car out onto the street. HULL running. Police and SIRENS pursuing. He hurls the Fed Ex envelope into a dumpster. HELICOPTER light sweeps over him. As he cuts around a building, Taft opens a car door right into his face. Hull goes down hard.

dialogue.text: Eddie starts the car, and Hull rolls out the passenger door as the BMW races across the lot. Two black-and-whites and an unmarked converge on the stand. Hull can't reach his car. He vaults a metal rail and runs off between two buildings. Hernandez jumps out of an unmarked and races after him. Taft speeds the car out onto the street. HULL running. Police and SIRENS pursuing. He hurls the Fed Ex envelope into a dumpster. HELICOPTER light sweeps over him. As he cuts around a building, Taft opens a car door right into his face. Hull goes down hard.

segments.content: (into car radio)
He waves at the helicopter which goes away, kneels over Hull who is twitching spastically on the ground, gasping for air. Hernandez arrives carrying the Fed Ex envelope.

dialogue.text: He waves at the helicopter which goes away, kneels over Hull who is twitching spastically on the ground, gasping for air. Hernandez arrives carrying the Fed Ex envelope.

segments.content: (continuing)
Hull is astonished to look up and see Taft looming over him, the man he remembers from the videotape. He tries to speak:

dialogue.text: Hull is astonished to look up and see Taft looming over him, the man he remembers from the videotape. He tries to speak:

segments.content: (barely audible)
You...
(briefly puzzled)
Hull shakes head, winces.

character.name: Me? Of course, it's me. You know me?

dialogue.text: Hull shakes head, winces.

segments.content: (continuing)
Hull tries to curse.

dialogue.text: Hull tries to curse.

segments.content: (continuing)
Here, I want to show you something.
He takes out his wallet, opens it to pictures of his two children, a boy and a girl, seven and eight.

dialogue.text: He takes out his wallet, opens it to pictures of his two children, a boy and a girl, seven and eight.

segments.content: (continuing)
These are mine. Aren't they the most
beautiful children you ever saw?
Hull groans, twists in pain. Taft sticks the pictures in his
face. Hull is affected by the children despite everything.
(continuing)
Yeah, I know, they kind of leave you
speechless. So let me ask, if someone
put a gun to your baby's head,
wouldn't you kill him if you could?
Hull just looks up.
(continuing)
Me, too. And you're the bastard with
the gun.
He takes the Fed Ex envelope from him.
(hoarse; his first
words)
You know the difference between a
nigger and a black man?
Don't jive me, boy.
The nigger's the one covers Whitey's
ass by puttin' the brothers in jail.
Taft yanks him hard to his feet; Hull cries out in pain.

INT. COURTROOM - NIGHT Hull is led in with other handcuffed PRISONERS. Carver is here, catches Hull's eye. Hull shakes his head; doesn't want Carver to intercede. A woman PUBLIC DEFENDER (26, attractive, harried) addresses the prisoners.

dialogue.text: INT. COURTROOM - NIGHT Hull is led in with other handcuffed PRISONERS. Carver is here, catches Hull's eye. Hull shakes his head; doesn't want Carver to intercede. A woman PUBLIC DEFENDER (26, attractive, harried) addresses the prisoners.

segments.content: Hi, I'm Shelley Weissbrod. This is
only an arraignment, a preliminary
hearing, but if you don't have money
for an attorney, the Public Defender's
office can...
Hull is listening to this when a BAILIFF taps his shoulder.
Puzzled, Hull sees the back of a suit conferring with a PROSECUTOR. The suit turns. It's DAVID ELIAS who smiles, offers his hand. Hull is stunned. Elias enjoys that.

dialogue.text: Puzzled, Hull sees the back of a suit conferring with a PROSECUTOR. The suit turns. It's DAVID ELIAS who smiles, offers his hand. Hull is stunned. Elias enjoys that.

segments.content: You're a lawyer??
I'm your lawyer.
Who hired you?
(smiles)
It's pro bono. If you don't want me,
there's Shelley. She's good. She
just can't provide special services...
Like what?
(calling the next
case)
John Hull...
Elias addressing the court.

dialogue.text: Elias addressing the court.

segments.content: (continuing)
Your Honor, I believe the preliminary
police toxicology report will show
that the substance seized from my
client was Mannitol, a baby laxative.
Hull is surprised at this news. The Judge looks to the Prosecutor who waives objection. Gavel.

dialogue.text: Hull is surprised at this news. The Judge looks to the Prosecutor who waives objection. Gavel.

segments.content: (continuing; to Hull)

As they walk toward the back, Taft approaches Hull. There's already a deep pull between these two, and in Taft's presence, Hull can't sustain the tough street act. We almost see the little boy inside him.

dialogue.text: As they walk toward the back, Taft approaches Hull. There's already a deep pull between these two, and in Taft's presence, Hull can't sustain the tough street act. We almost see the little boy inside him.

segments.content: (to Hull, amused)
Baby laxative, they sold you some
bad shit.
(to Hull)
You have a constipated baby, and
you're in jail? What kind of a father
are you?
A father who don't know his own
children, ain't that right?
A long look between them, broken when Elias takes Hull's
arm, leads him away. Elias cheerfully greets a couple of
hookers waiting arraignment. Hull furtively grabs his sleeve.
(under his breath)
You sold me Mannitol, motherfucker.
(under his)
If it hadn't been, asshole, you'd be
in jail right now... Come on, I want
you to meet some people.

After hours. The place is closed. A couple of cars in the 

               lot. Elias's BMW pulls in.

Deserted except for one table where Eddie, Barbosa, Gopher 

               and Chino are eating shrimp. They look up as Hull and Elias 

               approach. Eddie's astonished to see Hull.
Dudley, Dudley, Fo-Fudley...
Eddie looks around, uneasy.

dialogue.text: Eddie looks around, uneasy.

segments.content: (continuing)
John got busted and kept his mouth
shut. Can't say that for everybody,
can we?
What are you saying? Are you saying
me? Are you saying something about
me?
Tell the truth, Eddie. Be honorable.
It's all you got left.
Shut up, you little faggot.
The cops made you give them somebody.
Eddie looks around. Everybody's looking at him. He considers lying, but realizes it's pointless.

dialogue.text: Eddie looks around. Everybody's looking at him. He considers lying, but realizes it's pointless.

segments.content: All right, so what? I mean, so what,
man? You got the money. Twenty-six
G. Twenty-six, David. Count it.
Next time you might trade us.
Never.
(turns to Barbosa)
Never, Felix, never. Come on, man,
you know I'd never...
Hull observes Barbosa become the power center.
(softly)
I know you never will.
Felix, no. Don't be... I'm worth
money to you. Let me give you money.
Why? You don't owe me anything.
Another twenty-six grand... Just to
show you... Fifty.
Why not a hundred?
(that's so much)
Barbosa's impassive.

dialogue.text: Barbosa's impassive.

segments.content: (continuing)
Okay, a hundred.
Give it.
Tomorrow. Twenty-four hours.
Now. Ten seconds.
Felix, I need time. I --
One... two...
I don't have it right now. But I can --
(sadly)
Then goodbye, Eddie. I forgive you
for what you said to me.
(pleading)
Twelve hours. Tomorrow morning.
Six... seven...
(to Elias)
Elias looks stricken. Barbosa laughs. Eddie jumps up. Hull turns away, can't bear to watch this.

character.name: You want to do it, David?

dialogue.text: Elias looks stricken. Barbosa laughs. Eddie jumps up. Hull turns away, can't bear to watch this.

segments.content: (continuing)

EDDIE grabs the first thing he lays eyes on, a tiny snail fork and plunges it into Barbosa's neck. As if it were a fly bite, Barbosa flings the table aside and, with a long knife already in his hand, guts Eddie from groin to breast bone. Eddie falls like a suddenly emptied sack. Elias can't help gasping. Hull looks away, hiding his horror. Barbosa rips the fork out of his neck and hurls it at the body.

dialogue.text: EDDIE grabs the first thing he lays eyes on, a tiny snail fork and plunges it into Barbosa's neck. As if it were a fly bite, Barbosa flings the table aside and, with a long knife already in his hand, guts Eddie from groin to breast bone. Eddie falls like a suddenly emptied sack. Elias can't help gasping. Hull looks away, hiding his horror. Barbosa rips the fork out of his neck and hurls it at the body.

segments.content: Elias stares at Eddie's body, transfixed. Horrified, fascinated, afraid, in awe. Barbosa turns to Hull.

dialogue.text: Elias stares at Eddie's body, transfixed. Horrified, fascinated, afraid, in awe. Barbosa turns to Hull.

segments.content: (continuing)
What'd you think?
At least it was clean.
(pleased, to Elias)
What about you, bar mitzvah body?
First time you saw somebody die?
(eyes fixed on the
body)
No.
(catching breath)
At camp... when I was fourteen... a
friend of mine was water skiing...
The motorboat ran him over... A junior
counsellor was driving.
You should kill a man some day, David,
it's liberating...
(walking out)
Summer camp. I'm in business with
somebody who went to summer camp.
Everyone else is silent, grave.

heading.raw_text: INT. ELIAS'S HOUSE - KITCHEN - EARLY MORNING

segments.content:
Through sliders we see a small pool. Elias and Hull sit over 

               uneaten omelets. Both still shaken by the previous scene.
Eddie, man... He was always nice to
my daughter.
How'd a guy like you get into this?
The way most drug lawyers do: clients
paid me in product, and I had to
move it. Soon I was doing more dealing
than law. But this was '83, '84,
there was so much money we thought
it would never end.
Yeah. And now...?
The road gets rougher. Cocaine's a
dying business.
Then what are we doing here?
People are always going to want to
get high. Every society has ways to
alter consciousness.
Because they can't bear reality.
(smiles)
We all need our delusions, only the
means change: psychedelics, opiates,
prayer, orgies, human sacrifice...
Elias puts a finger to his lips.

dialogue.text: Elias puts a finger to his lips.

segments.content: (continuing)
Why aren't you selling it?
I know how to make it and market it.
But I need capital. That's the only
reason I'm hanging out with an asshole
like Barbosa.
(feels his hatred of
Barbosa)
And because I can't get to the big
guys.
Who are the big guys?
Gallegos, et cetera.
(reacts to the name)
Why can't you get to them?
Hull shrugs: he doesn't.

dialogue.text: Hull shrugs: he doesn't.

segments.content: (continuing)
Anyway, designer drugs have a bad
name: ice, ecstasy, tar -- there's a
limited market for Parkinson's
disease. But what about completely
safe, almost legal, terrific shit
you can go to work on and do your
job better than you ever did it
straight?
They hear someone coming.

dialogue.text: They hear someone coming.

segments.content: (closing the subject)
In dreams begin responsibilities.
Tell me about this new shit.
Some other time, John, when we know
each other better.
(as Miranda enters
kitchen)
Hey, bunnela.
(she snuggles against
him; Elias enjoys it)
Five times two.
He hugs her, kisses her, much more openly affectionate than Hull was with his own children. Hull notices that.

character.name: It's too early. Don't bother me.

dialogue.text: He hugs her, kisses her, much more openly affectionate than Hull was with his own children. Hull notices that.

segments.content: (continuing; head in
her father's chest)
Elias whispers in her ear.

dialogue.text: Elias whispers in her ear.

segments.content: (continuing)
Oh, yeah... Ten... Who's he?
That's my friend, John. This is
Miranda.
Miranda gives Hull a shy greeting. Nancy hurries into the kitchen, handsome, busy, ready for work.

dialogue.text: Miranda gives Hull a shy greeting. Nancy hurries into the kitchen, handsome, busy, ready for work.

segments.content: Come on, honey...
Nancy nods briefly in Hull's direction. Elias kisses Miranda who grabs the back-pack her mother proffers, and they go out. When they're gone:

dialogue.text: Nancy nods briefly in Hull's direction. Elias kisses Miranda who grabs the back-pack her mother proffers, and they go out. When they're gone:
